IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Maryland State Police, Barrack "D"
Unmarked MSP Vehicle D-17. In-Car Camera Operational.

Defendant: Alfonso-Vazquez, Sergio        
Date of Birth: 05/03/1974
Date of Arrest: 05/13/2023
Time of Arrest: 1740 hours
DUI #: 23-129 (Bel Air)
Blood test Result: .22 Br AC

BEHAVIOR/CONDUCT: Alfonso-Vazquez was cooperative and polite

CERTIFICATION & TRAINING
NHSTA Trained/certified to conduct Standardized Field Sobriety Test (SFST)
Preliminary breath test operator certified
Certified Radar/Laser Operator

VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1)
On 05/13/2022 at approximately 1652 hours, I, Trooper Kumador #7052 of the Maryland State Police, Bel Air Barrack was dispatched to Southbound MD-24 in the area of I-95 in Abingdon, Harford County, Maryland in reference to motor vehicle collision. I arrived on scene and observed a Hispanic male driver seated behind the wheel of a Cream Subaru Outback displaying Maryland registration 50303CL with heavy front-end damage. I also observed a Black Honda Civic with damage to the rear bumper area. Both vehicles pulled on the right shoulder. EMS and Fire board were on scene. Lane 2 was shut down by the Fire board. It was raining. 

PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2)
I made a driver side approach of the Subaru and made contact with the male Hispanic driver. I introduced myself and asked him if he was OK to which he stated yes. I asked him if he was the driver, and he said yes. I asked him if he needs medication attention, and he stated No. He appeared drowsy and his eyes appeared bloodshot, which is indicative of someone being under the influence. I asked him to exit his vehicle to speak with me outside. He exited the vehicle holding the door for support. I asked him what happened, and he stated he does not know. I asked him if he had taken any medication and he stated no.

I detected the odor of alcoholic beverage on his breath as he spoke with me outside. I asked him how much alcoholic beverage he had consumed, and he stated that he consumed three bottles of Corona Beers at his friend's house in Bel Air about an hour or two before the collision. I later identified the driver as Alfonso-Vazquez, Sergio, DOB 05/03/1974 and asked him to go back to his vehicle, to which he did. Alfonso-Vazquez later exited his vehicle the second time and started urinating in public right in front of my patrol vehicle on camera. 
          
PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3)     
Due to the overwhelming odor of alcoholic beverage emitting from Alfonso-Vazquez's breath, the admission to consuming alcoholic beverages an hour before the collision and the negligent manner of operating his vehicle resulting collision, on the highway, I had reasons to believe that Alfonso-Vazquez was driving under the influence of alcohol. I requested an additional unit and upon arrival, I asked Alfonso-Vazquez to exit his vehicle to perform Standardized Field Sobriety Tests to which he complied. The evaluation was performed on the right shoulder in front of my patrol vehicle. The shoulder was flat and free of any debris and the temperature was approximately 81 degrees. I asked Alfonso-Vazquez the following questions: Contacts-No, Glasses-No, and Any Injuries-No. Any medication: No.
 
HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS (6/6 clues observed)
The first test given was the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test. The tip of my index finger was used as the Test’s stimulus and held approximately 12 inches from Alfonso-Vazquez's eyes. He was instructed to look straight ahead, keeping his head still while following and focusing on the tip of the stimulus with his eyes until told to stop. I asked him if he understood the directions and he advised yes. His pupils were equal in size and did show equal tracking.
  • Lack of Smooth Pursuit-present 
  • The distinct and sustained Nystagmus at maximum deviation–present 
  • The onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees–present.
  • Vertical-present

WALK AND TURN (7/8)
Before Alfonso-Vazquez performed the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. He was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel-to-toe. He was instructed to place his hands flat at his side and to remain in the position until told to begin. He was advised to take nine (9) steps on a straight-line touching heel to toe on every step. He was to keep his hands flat at his side, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step out loud. On the ninth step, he was demonstrated and explained to keep his lead foot on the line and to take a series of small steps around to his left with his rear foot to turn completely around. He was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identically to the first series. He was then instructed that once he began the test he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keep his hands down by his side, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud.

During the instructional stage: I explained and demonstrated the starting position to Alfonso-Vazquez and placed him in the starting position. He could not stand straight in the starting position. He broke his feet more than multiple times. He could not remain in the starting position before the instruction.

Walking stage (1st Nine). 
  • Raised his arms more than 6 inches throughout the test.
  • Stopped walking on the 13th step and asked a question.
  • Missed heel-to-toe by more than an inch
  • Stepped offline during the test steps.
  • He took 13 steps.

Turn:
The turn was unsatisfactory. Alfonso-Vazquez did not turn as instructed.  He turned in one fluid motion instead of taking a small series of steps toward his left as he was instructed.

Walking stage (2nd Nine). 
  • Raised his arms more than 6 inches throughout the test.
  • Missed heel-to-toe by more than an inch
  • Stepped offline during the test steps.
  • He took 14 steps instead of 9.

ONE LEG STAND (3/4)
Prior to Alfonso-Vazquez performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. He was instructed to stand with his heels together and hands down by his side, while the instructions were given and during the test. He was instructed not to begin the test until he was instructed to start. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately 6 inches. While his leg was raised, he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one-thousand-one, one thousand-two), and to continue the test until told to stop.
  • He raised his arms during the test. 
  • He swayed side by side during the test.
  • He put his foot down countless time

PRELIMINARY BREATH  
A preliminary breath test was explained and offered to Alfonso-Vazquez and voluntarily submitted to the test with a result of .18 Br Ac.
 
ARREST
Based on the following, I have reasons to believe that Alfonso-Vazquez was operating his vehicle while under the influence of alcohol and unable to operate safely resulting in a collision.
  • Extremely strong odor of alcoholic beverage on his breath
  • Negligent driving resulting in two vehicle collision
  • Admission to consuming alcoholic beverages an hour or more before the traffic stop,
  • Observed signs of impairment as he performed the Standardized Field Sobriety Tests unsatisfactorily.
I arrested Alfonso-Vazquez at 1740 hours for driving his vehicle while under the influence of alcohol. Alfonso-Vazquez listened to the Spanish audio version of DR-15 Advice of Rights in its entirety in my patrol vehicle and at the conclusion, he voluntarily agreed to submit to the test. He signed the paper copy of the DR-15 at the barrack at 1804 hours.  I transported Alfonso-Vazquez to the Maryland State Police, Bel Air barrack for processing. Alfonso-Vazquez also had an active warrant through the Harford County District Court for failure to appear. 
 
20-MINUTES OBSERVATION PERIOD.  
Alfonso-Vazquez observation started as soon as he was arrested and his oral cavity check was completed.

INTOXIMETER RESULT:   
Breath test was explained and offered to Alfonso-Vazquez by Sgt. Stanley #5405 with result of .22 Br Ac
 
Alfonso-Vazquez was charged with driving a vehicle while under the influence of alcohol and other DUI related charges.
Alfonso-Vazquez was given copies of all pertinent paperwork and later transported to the Harford County Detention Center to see the District Court Commissioner for his bench warrant.

Closed by arrest. 

All events occurred in Harford County, Maryland.
